Title: Prove $(a_1+b_1)^{1/n}\cdots(a_n+b_n)^{1/n}\ge \left(a_1\cdots a_n\right)^{1/n}+\left(b_1\cdots b_n\right)^{1/n}$
Content: consider positive numbers $a_1,a_2,a_3,\ldots,a_n$ and $b_1,b_2,\ldots,b_n$. does the following in-equality holds and if it does then how to prove it $\left[(a_1+b_1)(a_2+b_2)\cdots(a_n+b_n)\right]^{1/n}\ge \left(a_1a_2\cdots a_n\right)^{1/n}+\left(b_1b_2\cdots b_n\right)^{1/n}$
AcceptedAnswer: Apply the AM-GM inequality to the sequence $a_k/(a_k+b_k)$ and then to the sequence $b_k/(a_k+b_k)$. Add the resulting two inequalities, and multiply through by $\left(\prod_k (a_k+b_k)\right)^{1/n}$ to get the result. This is exercise 2.11 (page 34) of J. Michael Steele's The Cauchy-Schwarz Master Class , and the result is there credited to Minkowski. This inequality is sometimes called the "superadditivity of the geometric mean".

Multiplying both sides by $\binom{n}{k}$:

$$
\sum_{|S|=k} \prod_{i \in S} a_i \prod_{i \notin S} b_i \geq \binom{n}{k} G_a^k G_b^{n -k}
$$

Thus, each term in the expansion of the LHS is at least as large as the corresponding term in the binomial expansion of $(G_a + G_b)^n$. Therefore, summing over all k from 0 to n, we get:

$$
\prod_{i=1}^n (a_i + b_i) \geq \sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k} G_a^k G_b^{n -k} = (G_a + G_b)^n
$$

Taking the nth root of both sides gives the desired inequality:

$$
\left( \prod_{i=1}^n (a_i + b_i) \right)^{1/n} \geq G_a + G_b
$$

Therefore, the inequality holds, and equality occurs when equality holds in each AM-GM step. This happens when, for each k, all the terms $\prod_{i \in S} a_i \prod_{i \notin S} b_i$ are equal for all subsets S of size k. This condition implies that all the a_i's are equal and all the b_i's are equal. Specifically, if there exists constants a and b such that $a_i = a$ and $b_i = b$ for all i, then equality holds. More generally, equality holds when the ratio $a_i/b_i$ is constant for all i.

Thus, the inequality is proven using the AM-GM inequality applied to each subset of the product terms.
